Remsen, June 20th - (Tuesday)
Dear John,
Your mother returned from Saratoga last evening. Lewis had returned on Saturday, a week ago last Saturday - Your mother remained there a little over one week. They reached on Friday eve (the 9th) Sarah was much fatigued and had spasms rather bad - the following day Saturday had spasms much worse - but was better the following day, and on Monday was comfortable, and from that day has been under treatment. Your mother has considerable confidence in Dr. Strong and his wife, and in their treatment. Sarah was rather improving in some things - and had not had any more of the spasms. - She felt happy in her new situation, surrounded by many affectionate and sympathysing friends. Let us try to remember her in our daily supplication, at the throne of grace, to which I hope and trust, Dear John, you are not an entire stranger. Your mother seems about as well as when she left home. We continue in the family the plan of having subjects to recite verses on - the one last week was "Benevolence" - this week "the future state". Your letter from Auburn I recvd the following day, after you wrote - and on the morning following (Friday I think or Thursday) I sent it on with a few lines from myself - to Philadelphia. I shall be expecting daily now for an answer - it may come this evening. - If it comes today or tomorrow I will forward it to you, care of Rev. Thos Evans, Youngstown - if later, I will send to meet you at Pittsburgh, Care of Mister D. E. Evans. We are getting along tolerably well with Cenhadwr - Did not commence setting till the 5th having had to clean and white wash the office. today we are printing the last face of 1st Form - and have 2 galleys towards next form set - Anna helps some. Gth Jones is with us today howing potatoes. Lewis & Eddy ploughed them on Saturday. We are all well at home - had a letter a few days ago from Iarthryn? Gwyned - he is going to leave for America with his family in August. Sold one U.T.C.? to Levi James, yesterday. Hope you will be careful of your health - not to be too ardent, and work too hard. Better do a little and have your health improved, than do more, and to fail in health. Mother wrote to Sarah Mariah at Saratoga, and finishes it today, to which the girls are adding some. Your Sister's address is care of Dr. E. S. Strong, Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Robt & Jane are well. Your father,  all joining in love & c  R. E.

Remsen, July 4. 1854 Dear John Yours of June 29, Pittsburgh, we received last evening (Monday,) and were happy to find that you felt better, and had met with some kindness at Pittsburgh. We are writing today to Sarah Maria. I have a $10 bill in the house and will send it to her, and get the same amount again of Robert - so that will be as payment of $10 from Robert. I think I will send today a few numbers for July to Mr D. E. Evans and also to Mr. D Edwards, and will pay the postage of these two parcels, that they may have them in hand to use, if called for. - I think it is best to let them get subscribers than for you to do it. - I am sending this to Ebensburg, where it will meet you I hope in safety. Try all you can to talk Welsh - the Welsh people will love to hear Welsh talk, though it be broken, - and using will rub off the rust. - I will try to find the portrait and the cut you mentioned, and send them. I will write to Mr. Edwards and Mr Evans. - Please write often. - You can tell better than we can with reference to the Atlas. Perhaps if you do not see it best to take it, you had better drop them a line to give the reason of your declining. - We mailed the Cenhadwr on Saturday. Sent you a No. - We had one letter from Sarah since your mother came home - She was comfortable, and hopeful. It was written by some friend for her. We hope to have a letter again from her - perhaps this eveng. - I will write again to meet you at Pittsburgh care of D E Evans - We all join in love to you. - Your affectionate father   Robt Everett.

My Dear Son Lewis -

We had to return this morning, Wed. June 23 to Milwaukee, so as to meet another train for Cambria, where we have to be to hold a meeting this eveng and tomorrow all day - then to Spring Grove or Janesville and to Dodgeville against the Sabbath. - I have had no letter from home since I left Racine - John's letter has not been received - We started this morning about 5 o clock  - rode about 5 or 6 miles, in a Buggy - then about 26 mi in the cars - and have again 77 mi to Cambria. I am staying at the house of one Mr Edwards to write this letter, a very pleasant family - I am rocking the cradle for their little baby while writing this letter - I love to look a little children more than ever - thinking how the Savior took them in his arms and blessed them. We want to feel more for the lambs of the flock, the mother of this tale is very feeble.  Yesterday morning we rode to meeting Rev. J. Pary? & myself about 3 miles in a rough Waggon drawn by two oxen - the horses had gone astray in the night - but were afterwards found - We are quite well this morning - Rev. E. Griffiths came with us to Waukesha, but is to return to Racine today. - We expect to be at Racine Tuesday eveng June 29 - Wed June 30 N Chicago - then to visit Uncle's two or three days, & Big Rock on the Sabbath July 4.

If I go to Cattaraugus - against the 11th I shall have to go alone - I do not know what is best to do - Mr. Price will have to return against that Sabbath - if not against the 4th and let me go alone to Big Rock - I am not sure about that - as he expects daily a letter from home to say whether they have a supply in Utica or not for that Sabbath - it is their communion Sabbath. - Give my kind respects to Mr W. D. W. who I expect will be with you next Sabbath. - Let me know who has been fixed upon to be invited to our Cymanfa. - With much love to you all at home, Your affe father R. Everett.

  We have a long and tedious journey to Dogeville against next Sabbath - I wish now the arrangement had not been made by Mr. G., Racoine, to have us go so far. - I feel quite will this morng - It is a warm sultry day - This is a large city of about 25 vans? standing.

Racine, almost as nice as at Steuben - Love to Aunty, am glad she keeps in so well - and is so good - We have had no rain hardly for the last 8 or 10 days - I expect the Ohio farmers have by this time finished planting their corn. Your affte father,

Dodgeville, 8 1/2 A.M. June 28. 1858.
Dear Lewis - 
Please send Cenhadwr X from January 1858 to to Mr John W. Hughes, Dodgeville, Iowa Co., Wis. - If this comes to hand before you send off July No., send them in the parcel to Dodgeville - if not, send the parcel to J. W. Hughes, Dodgeville - We had large congregations yesterday - very good attention - were much fatigued last evening having travelled in rough waggon against 10 o clock about 7 mi to Capel Coed, and thence to Dodgeville 7 or 8 mi further - it was about the hottest day we have had yet. - We have to go 11 miles against 10 this morning - then about 6 or 7 against 4 P.M. - Mr Pierce Owens, son of the late Ellis Owens is with his waggon at the door to take us this morng - I feel quite well and must close this - love to you all - 
your affte father R. Everett.

Brooklyn, Oct 17 1959 - Monday.-

Dear Lewis - 

The Letter of Saturday from the girls containing the one from John with the $10 inclosed came this morning. - Thomas I think the bill is good - he has taken it to see - we are all well. - Our Cymanfa is to begin on next Friday evening. Your mother and myself took tea at J. M. Jones' last Friday - they are well - Mrs Jones sends her likeness with us to her father - We are very glad to hear that Mrs. Mary Davies is better - hope she may get well again. - Jane has not seen the Doctor since Tuesday evening - Friday & Saturday evenings he had gone to see a sick patient some distance, and would not return till late - Jennie gains but slowly, still we hope she does gain some - we must not be too sanguine our hopes. She and mother expect to see the Dr. this evening. - We had a good day yesterday - weather good & cory? pretty full. - I am sending a little acct of the meeting to the "Synagogue" on Saturday in this - With love to you and Jane & the little ones and all the rest at home I rem^n your father in haste Robt Everett.

Remsen July 20 74
My Dear Daughter
Herein we send you a PO Order for $50 on Station & New York —
Also we happened to have an order for $1.50 on New York instead of Remsen.
This order you can have by calling at the Post Office of New York City — this will be a little in addition to the other. You will have to sign your name it. 
We are all in usual health this afternoon — and send love to you.
Your father
Robert Everett
I believe I gave your address to Morgan Owen as "333 W 14th Street" instead of W 34th St — but I hope that will not hinder you to get the money.

Dec 3 73
Dear Mary  we faild to have the Cenhadwr ready till today and we have only one bag ready today viz the Chicago Bag - the others we will send tomorrow

The PO Order for $30 was duly received - We were sorry not to have you keep this sum as you needed it - We have - been quite short of money lately but hope it will be better soon - This Note must be brief - as Gwen is going this morning to the Mail - Send again if you need help - we are all well this morning & send our love 

your father R E

May 25 74
My Dear Daughter, 
I find by your last letters that Mrs Jones and friends are to leave New York on Saturday- But I fear the Cenhadwr will not be out by that day - it would have to leave Remsen on Tuesday and I fear we cannot get it out by that day.

 Please ask Mrs Jones whether we could send a June No for her to some place in the old country - if so, where? also August.
 The unclear by Rev D Price will be in June No.
 all well
 Yr father - 
 R E

Dear Robert + Mary
Quite a sudden death has again occurred in our neighborhood — Mr Russell Fuller having been ailing for 9 days or a fortnight, and yet going around in the house and about —on Saturday evening last was struck with palsy or apoplexy and died on Monday morning — to be buried today — am going there this morning with your mother to the funeral at 11. — We are quite anxious to hear from you both to know how you are getting along. — The roads are blocked up with snow very much — must go around through the village today. — Lewis went up afoot yesterday afternoon to O.W.'s.  We are all well as usual. — Have not heard from John or Jane or Elizabeth, since we wrote to you last — Have now been near a fortnight without hearing from John. 
All joining in love to you, I close this in haste as it is time to go. —
Your father
R. Everett
Wednesday
March 12, 1856

would Mary Like to have father send her some money he might send seventy dollars Sarah had a kind letter from Dr Strong he asks for you both and sends kind respects the cars did not come any farther than Trenton monday

Remsen, March 19 1855 (Monday.) 
Dear Robert

 We have had our paper up from New York got it home on Saturday - the Bill was $305,55 - of which Mr E Lewis has paid $150 - in New York to meet the Balance I am short of about $30 or $35 - Could you lend me that sum -  I hope I could refund it about the 1st of April -  or $50 wd be preferable that I may not have to hand out all my hard cash.  Mr John K Richards has in hand for me, payments due for last year - which may be from $15 to $20 - Suppose you take a ride up to see him tomorrow morning before breakfast (Tuesday) or evening - He would hand you the money immediately - in which case, and if you have Mr Richards' money, I may need to borrow but little, if any. - Please call today again at Mr Maxwell's and see how he gets along with his binding - Answer this if you please tomorrow morning - Sarah & Cynthia (Lewis accompanying them) are going to Saratoga on Wednesday or Thursday of this week. With love to you and Jane - I am you afft father Robt Everett.  I intend to send the money down to be forwarded by Express.

March 23. 1855 Dear Robert  Herein you will find Mr Gray's Bill - Should he continue 3 months longer. 1/5 would be deducted instead of 1/10. - We have no letter here whatever for Margaret Morris - I do not know when John left - I think he sent it to Waterville. - We are all well - Your affte father. - Robert Everett. I do not know whether Evans & Richards have paid any on their Bill or not - I have not acct of it, if they have. - I do not know whether it is best to hand them their bill now, or not. Mother had 3 pairs of every day stockings mended for Jennie but in the hurry forgot to send them by Lewis -

Remsen, Feb 19. 1856. - Dear Robert and Mary - Snow storms and snow drifts seem to break up communications between us. This last storm seemed to vie with its predecessors in sublimity and grandeur. I failed to go to Penymnydd last Sabbath - did not attempt it - mother and the girls would not let me try - there was so little hope that I could get through if I had started - and it was rough and very cold. Today is calm and pleasant - almost as if the harbinger of opening spring weather. We are quite anxious to hear how Robert is, and Mary also. Hope there will be a letter or two from you this afternoon - we have had no mail since Saturday. The office folks are getting along very well - all quite busy - the first 16 pages have been printed and the 2nd form of 8 pages are being printed today - and most of next form has been set. The satchel with Robert's things was sent down against 9 o clock, to be out by the cars - but the cars had only reached from Barnsville to Remsen last evening and had gone their way towards Uttica at 7 oclock - we will send it this afternoon, should the cars go - We are all well - mother's sore thumb almost well. - All uniting in love  both, I remain Your affte father Robt Everett.

Welsh words at top crossed out
Dear Robert In examining our Mail Book we have found that nearly one = half of our subscribers for Detholyd, at the commencement of the year had paid for the whole year, though we had said that they might send payment for 6 months only if they choose to do so- We have therefore concluded to continue the publication to the end of the year, at least. --- Please to do with as well as you can -- We are all well at home except your mother - she has felt somewhat unwell for two or three Days. -- John is about the same -- a little better, I think. Your affectionate father R. Everett. 
We have a young people's prayer meeting this evening page torn
Dear Robert

How are you getting along? A young man with whom I rode from Utica in the stage (Humphreys by name, a clerk at Dana's) told me he went to your old room on Whitesboro street that morning to get 3 Daguerreotypes but you were not there and he concluded you had left the city, so he went to Dave's. So you see some of your near neighbors have not learnt where you are. But I guess they will find out bye-and-bye. What kind of fan advertisement have you got in the Am. Baptist?

Henry says he saw an awfully bungling one in it a few weeks ago --- the new caption116 Genesee St., but the old advertisement about "the rage for skylights in our great cities"! I got a note from Ebenezer Tucker last Saturday. He is now engaged in collecting money to endow a colored school in Indiana of which he is the principal. He is going to call with us next Thursday. He will spend next Sabbath in Steuben & Remsen. We expect him to preach and state the object of his mission in the morning in Capel Nohu; and he is to be in Morris Roberts church in the evening. Could not you manage to spend next Sabbath at home, so that we could spend one day all together. I think it would revive Old Oneida Institute remembrances pleasantly. & try to come if you can. William can be in the room early Monday morning. Your brother John
P.S. We are sending the Detholyd down to-morrow morning, and you will probably have them before this reaches you.

Dear Son Robert - Please to see if there is a small parcel of type for us at Express Office and send it up - Also please to see if the Box of Hymn Books have come up by Rail  Road - If it is come, you will take it in, and pay the freight, and let Mr Evan Ellis have as many as he wishes to have of the Hymn Books.  - Perhaps 20 or so will answer - of the gilt ones at $1. He does not want the 10/book.- Call about every other day at the Rail Road place, till you get them - We are in usual health - Sarah rather better. From your affectionate father R. E. - Tuesday afternoon Mr Bruce promised to send me the a's instead of the imperfect ones - Also rules for music font instead of imperfect ones - this is what I expect by Express - and we need them immediately -

Mr Robt Everett Junr
Daguerrean Rooms
Utica  N.Y.

Whitesboro  June 29. 1848

Dear Sarah.   It is now about a week since you went to that awful place as you call it. probably it seems somewhat less awful now than at first.  Sure it is, I could not see anything so very dismal about it, on the contrary  I think it quite a desirable location if one is out of health, indeed, I should like to be with you there this minute, and would if I could fly. Should like nothing better. Suppose you have become quite initiated into baths, and sheets, and packs, by this time, though you could give me an introduction should I visit you?  Jane has gone home and you do not know how lonely it seems here. And Sarah too gone, it seems as though we had lost half of the house. Robert brought me today some of the nicest milk, wish you and Mother could be here that I might make you some good sweet custard. Have you moved into your nice little room in the third story yet?  Wish I could drop in this afternoon and see how you look. our house is getting along slowly - it will be a month yet probably before we can get settled.The term is about closing up at the Seminary - the students are beginning to scatter. Write to me soon and tell me all about yourself.  Your affectionate Sister  Elisabeth

written on left side and across top:
Sat morn. I've received your very welcome notes this morning. Am glad to learn that you are both getting more contented. Wish you could have reported more decided improvement in your health, though in a short time we could not expect a great change. Have just been making some pumpkin pies with that milk that Robert brought, wish I could send you some. But I suppose you think that water is better than all the pumpkins and everything else that you can think of

But it is time that this should go to the office. Hope you will get it today. You do not know how glad we were to hear from you - hope you will write as often as you can. Thank Mother particularly for her note - it is so seldom that we get anything from her - with love from Mr Butler and myself  I remain your affectionate Daughter? & sister  E.E. Butler

Whitesboro Friday 2, P.M.
Dear Sister Sarah...
It may seem odd to you that Elizabeth and I are such near neighbors as to write to you both on the same sheet. Father was going to the meeting in Bethania this morning So I thought I had "got a" good "chance" to take a ride with him and come on to Whitesboro. On the way I am having a new dash board and other fixings for the buggy. It will be all in rig Monday. I think some of comeing to see you Monday. Father has to go to Rome next Wednesday, on account of Mr Evans' will and he fears that he will not be able to come to Graefenburg till the week after next. But if mother is not a going to stay much over a  fortnight he would come on Thursday. We received your joint letter last night and were glad to hear that your home fever was subsiding. Water must be a capitol thing for fevers. Father and I wrote you last Tuesday the day after I got home. We got through with the Cenhadwr last night. except a few. The boys have done well in the office. Henry staid from school last week and Anna and Cynthia remained at home to help yesterday. Jane and Mary and cousin get along with the work  Father's health is good mine is better (than when I say you). John is middling. He had some rain in Steuben on Wednesday though not much. It threatened but kept calm. I suppose that was the day on which you letter was written from the circumstance that ma days it rained hard with you. Please date your next or say "Rainy day or "cold day. I wish that I could come to see you to day, but I must be at Bethania by 4 o'clock to go home with father to night. It is time to start. Goodbye

John sent mother a Cenhadwr by mail
 Robert

Dear Mother:
I have thought much of you since you have been at Graffenburg, a sort of exile. And hardly ever have you been pictured to my imagination, but shivering with cold and more than once have I wished that I could carry a good warm stove into your room that you might be a little more comfortable. We have had considerable cold weather since you have been there. This cold winter is almost too bad in cold chilly weather. Hope however that you do not suffer so much from cold as at first. I've felt very anxious to know how the weather is going to agree with your leg - Does Dr. Foster seem to understand your care and is he careful - hope he will not advise a course of treatment too severe for your strength. Are you not in need of something that I could send you from here - if so please inform us - Things move on here pretty much as usual - our vacation is just at hand - we shall probably spend most of it here. How do you and Sarah like those books I sent you. The memoir of Mrs. Prior, I think you will find very interesting and also "Judah's Lion." If you have not read the last mentioned I wish you would - I know you will like it. Any thing that has to do with with the Jewish nation is doubly interesting. Hope you will write us very soon, and tell us particularly about your health. With much love Your Affectionate Daughter Elizabeth
Written along the side: I have had a most miserable pen and no knife to mend it.

Miss Sarah A. Everett
New Graeffenberg
Utica

Remsen, Oct 7, 1851 -
My dear daughter - 

  As Jane is gone, I fear you will not receive letter from home quite so often. Jane & Mary left Utica as I understood from John at 10 o'clock Friday morng, and expected to be at Mt Holyoke that evening - Probably you will receive a letter from them before this reaches you. We have not had one as yet. Robert came home with John on Saturday evening - and both went off again to Utica yesterday Morning. John  wanted to go for some iron bar for the office - expect him back this evening - though it is uncertain, as it is now about tea time. Your Ma is in Whitesboro since a week today - have not heard from them since Saturday - your sister was comfortable there. and the baby doing well. Our family looks quite small now - only Anna & Eddy of our folks today, and Mary Jones, and the boys and Mr. Davies in the office. We feel cheered to hear from you time to time that you are "some better" - since your general health is gradually improving I feel that we ought to be very thankful - and that is all we can now expect. When you gain a little more strength I am expecting your spine complaint will yield gradually to the treatment - am glad your courage is kept up so well. Look to the Lord, dear daughter, for his blessing - We don't forget you before the throne of grace in the closet or in the family - hope you can cast all your burden on the Lord, and cheerfully confide in his wisdom and goodness, with reference to health and all things. I am anxiously looking for John's return that I may have something to say about them in Whitesboro.

- but probably he will not come tonight - it is now near ten. Mary Jones joins with your Sister Anna in love to you. Our "Cymanfa" was a good meeting throughout - good preaching at all the meetings, and solemn and melting attention in the congregations - great multitude present, especially in Capel Ucha. But we do not know, as yet, particularly of any conversions. Edward Josiah prays with us in the family sometimes now, and in prayer meetings - and David also. - But I must close - it is late, and I feel tired
Your affectionate father
Robt Everett
Wed. Morning - John did not come home last night - this $2 bill is for your private purse - I will send some more soon to Mr. K.-
Address
Miss Sarah A. Everett
care of Rev. H. H. Kellogg
Clinton

Remsen, Oct. 22, 1851
Dear Daughter Sarah -
We received your letter last evening, and were all glad to hear that your health continues to improve though but slowly. I send in this for Mr. Kellogg a Draft for $20,75 - I hope Mr. K can get the cash for it - if any of the merchants who have account in New York - We are all well at home - have not heard from Jane & Mary, excepting in a day or two after they moved there. I went down with your mother Monday to see Elizabeth & family and returned yesterday - Mother wanted much to come on to Clinton but I had to return on account of Cenhadwr work, as it is drawing near the close of the month. Your sister Elizabeth is quite comfortable - sits up - and goes around to the kitchen a little every day - the baby gets along well. Cynthia is there yet to take care of John Henry - Elizabeth was in Utica with Mr B. last Saturday She bore it pretty well, but was considerably tired after her ride  Mother should like to know if you will need some flannels this winter - and shall you need some other things from home - Please say in your next. Anna & Eddy will be looking for your letter next week. But you must be careful not to tire yourself too much in writing - they will not look for a long letter - We are afraid of your getting too much fatigued with writing - especially as you will now have to write to Mt. Holyoke also. - Be sure, daughter, not to write long letters and over fatiguing yourself with writing - tell them that they shall have the privilege of writing long letters, and you, short ones. -
All of us join in love to you - 
From your affectionate father
Robt Everett
Be sure to tell us when your pocket is nearly empty of a little cash.

Remsen, March 6, 1865

British School October 9th 1867 

My Dear Uncle & Aunt,
I am now addressing you for the first time.  Although I am nearly related and have heard of you from my childhood;. First of all I must tell you who I am, I am the eldest daughter living of your brother Thomas   I was born in America and came over when 3 years old with my Parents, so that I have no recolection about America having left it so young   I have been married since 11 years to a person teaching the British School in Denbigh, he is a native of Henlam his family are from Owen near Newmarket. His Father was second to you (Uncle Everett) my husband is upon the 17th year in Denbigh School. We have had 3 children, but only one is living. The one we have is a little girl of 7 years old.

I must say that providence had been very kind to me in giving me a kind husband, we do not live in affluence, still we have what we wish for to render us comfortable. My health not being strong it is better that I should not be under any anxiety in business & all that I have charge of is now my little girl, with my domestic duties   When single I had the management and charge of business with my sisters at Rhyl.  My husband has been a student at Bala College, he intended giving up the Public School and keeping a private one, he is getting tired of having many under his charge. We have been much interested in the company of Mr Butler an getting an account of you all as a family, as well as of his tour, I hope that he may return to his native land in safety having had his health greatly invigorated,

We feel it natural when we come in contact with any Publication from America, the Cenhadwr or anything else, to look for the names of our relative there, I assure you, we feel a warm attachment towards you all as a family, although we have been so very dilatory in writing  I enjoyed the company of Mr. Roberts when he was over last year and thought much of writing with him then but delay I did. My cousin Sarah wrote a letter to us 3 sisters some time ago, I think my sister Rachel keeps up a correspondence with your family since. I should very much like to hear from you and my cousins and have some of their likenesses  I send you mine and my husband.  My little girl has not had hers taken lately so that I have not one of hers. I think that I have said enough now or you will be tired of reading, all

the letters which you will receive by Mr Butler you see and hear all of our religious affairs, Please give our Kindest Love to all our Cousins and friends there

I remain your affectionate Niece   E F Ellis


Mr & Mrs Everett

Holywell Dec 26 . 1838 - 
My Dear Brother -

Being on a tour through Denbighshire to  Flintshire in behalf of the Dysgrdyd.  was in Greenfield yesterday all day. a meeting was held there, and this morning Mr. Simmons coll? at my cousin saying that he is starting for Stuben. next week and I thought that I would just write a line or two. I am off directly after my publication. I came through New market monday evening to Mostyn. I only stopt there a few minutes, I did not light. they were all well there but brother & sister. I found very low they had buried there Father just returned from the grave. (John Jones Nailer?) Sister Ann was there she is quite well. and family & I am glad to say also that my family at Home  -was quite well on Monday morning. except little Samuel. he is very weak this 5 or 6 months. Edw. is out of his pram? now at Xtmas. Thomas is very comfortable. has the management of a shop at Llanvinst?, London House - he has been received to communion

Dr Brother. I am glad to inform you that the course of Xh. amongst us at Llansuth & Trefnir is in a flourishing state. The sisters has a meeting at Llannust and also at Trefrin. there meetings are well attended are have also had church prayer meetings that is the church meeting all days to pray for revival of religion amongst us. These meetings are very preciouis - rest of page is in Welsh

this page is entirely in Welsh
signed Lewis Everett

Mr. Robt Everett
Stuben -
America

Wednesday Nov 30th 59 Dear Uncle It is Aunts wish that I should write you a few lines. She is very feeble indeed, has had sick spells now and then for three or four weeks. she seems failing very fast. and talks of dying. thinks she cannot possibly live until morning. She is very anxious to see you. Her cough is very bad. we have sent for the Doctor and expect him every moment. I

hope she may be relieved. she is greatly distressed in her stomach, She feels very much in need of her cotton flannel chemise. If you would like to see her please bring them. She wished me to ask you for her yarn. that was given her, she is very childish, we do not expect any different Aunt worries a great deal about her eyes she wants to see an Oculist, Mother thinks of taking her to Utica when she is better But would like your advise first. It is after 9 PM, I have written in great haste If Aunt should be worse I will write again directly We all join in love to your family   Jane  A Hughes

New York Mills Jan 30th
Dear Uncle,
I must write you a few hurried lines to say that Aunt Sarah is very sick indeed. She was taken in the middle of last night with a pain in her side which at times is very severe. Mother has been up ever since with her and will probably have to be up all night for she needs a great deal of care. She wished me to write to say she would like very much to see you. She says she thinks she will never see you and your

family again. She is afraid she cannot live untill morning. But I suppose her medicine makes her feel sick. I will lay this by untill morning and we can tell, how she may be then.
Sunday Evening Feb 3
I have delayed finishing this letter untill now hoping Aunt would get well, as she has been better and worse all the week, we could hardly tell how she was. Yesterday she was very sick all day, a little better this morning. In the afternoon she slept for a while. When she awoke I led her to a chair seeming very well. But in an instant she fainted entirely away. Her breath stoped and for a few moments we thought she was gone. But life returned, and she is now lying very sick indeed, we had a Doctor

last week, she says she will have him no more. If she must have one she wants her old Dr Price, It is only her notion. I merely write what she says to gratify her. Our Doctor is very good and if she is no better we will see what he can do for her, tomorrow. She wishes very much to see you and some of your family.
She seems a little comfortable now. I must close with love to all
From your niece J. A. Hughes
To  Robert Everett

New York Mills Dec 9th
Dear Uncle
I beg pardon for not answering your kind letter ere this. "But to be candid with you". I have not found time untill this eve to sit down and write you. As I told you, had, Aunt been worse I should have written directly. She was very sick a week ago but has since been on the increase so much so that this morning with a little help she was able to walk to Robert's - spent the day, came back this evening.
She is now feeling quite well. We hope she may not have a return of these

bad spells this winter.
In regard to her eyes, she feels more contented since you wrote so decided. We were all very much opposed to having them operated upon,
Aunt thanks you very kindly for the two Dollars you sent her. She thinks she will use it in getting he a new dress.
Please write to ous occasionally as it does aunt a great deal of good to hear from you. I will write again. We all join in love to you & family.
Your niece
J. A. Hughes

New York Mills May 27th
My dear Uncle,
Yours of the 17th was received with great sorrow. As is often said, "trouble never comes unattended" we feel it at this time, while we are lamenting poor Aunts illness, a greater sorrow hangs over us. The Brass Band have had a call to join the Army, the leader has gone to Albany to make arrangements if they prove satisfactory they will leave soon. Robert and Samuel are among the number that have enrolled their names, It is hard to part with them, but they feel it their duty to answer to the call, and

we must bid them ,,God speed"
Samuel has been very sick with the Diptheria, he has scarcely recovered his strength yet. I fear he will not stand it but we must bide our time, for he is determined to go. One of us would like very much to go and see Aunt, but we can not possibly now, we would spend every minute with the boys for it may be the last.
Times are very dull here Father is only working half time, any work has entirely stoped. Lewis has left William is with us still he can get no work, it is rather hard, But I must try and do something.
Please excuse and accept these few disconnected times for I have written with a heavy heart. 
Love to all,
Your affectionate niece J A Hughes

New York Mills Aug 5th 64
Dear Uncle- 
Mother wished me to write you, asking if you would when down at Utica come here and take Aunt Sarah with you. She wants to come very much every day she is complaining to go to Stueben, We dont know what to do; once or twice we have started her in the Stage, she would go, she would go as far as Utica then come and say she was afraid to go alone. Mother has asked her to go to Utica and ask Robert to let her go with him, but no that would not do, she said she would not go with him lest he would take her to the Asylum.If you are down next week and can possibly come here Mother would like to see you very much, Mother is very sick she was taken very sudenly last Sunday morning. Perhaps, Mothers being sick, is the cause of Aunts complaining more now than usual, She is not troublesome. dont do anything out of the way... no trouble to us whatever. We would take her if we could, but their is no one at home that can take her, and mother thought I had better write you and have you take when down if you possibly could
Your nephew
William Hughes

Thursday
Dear Aunt and Uncle
When I left Remsen I thought a week would hardly pass or a fortnight at the farthest before I should write to you, but it has been defered from one time to another, and week after week has passed without my writing a word to any one. I hope you will excuse my negligence as it was not intentional. the kindness of yourself and cousins in assisting and treating me so tenderly during my stay with you will always be remembered with feelings of affection and gratitude. I had hoped to receive a visit from some of you before this time, but have been disappointed, Cousin John called one evening with Cousin Robert, but stayed so short a time that it does not deserve the name of a visit. Cousin Mary & Henry and Sister Elizabeth came over one Saturday and spent the day with us, we had a very pleasant visit. I presume they think it would have been more agreeable if I had not kept them winding carpet rags all the while. But I did not cut them all, Mother and Sisters helped me until they were finished. We have not got our

furniture yet, I expect to go the last of this week and select the crockery and other things we shall need. Sisters Mary and Frances helped me make my Parlor carpet and three comfortables, it was more tedious to make the carpet than I expected. Father Lewis intends removing to Utica the first of next week, they would have left us two weeks ago, but Thomas requested them to stay to assist us in getting our work done, Father and brother Henry were here one Afternoon last week. They staid about two hours. It is the first time Father has called on me since I have been here, his health is quite poor this Spring though some better for a week or two past. Sister Leticia is very well and goes to school to Mrs Chapin, Sister Mary and myself called at the School house week before last to see her, Brother Alexander and Henry are very well and full of business as usual, I have not collected my school bills yet but expect to when the factory pays this month. When are you coming down to make us a visit I hope it will be soon, it seems an age since I left you, not that I am lonely here far from it, but I do so want to see you all, we have not been very highly favored with visits from our friends since I came here, though we have many promises of such. Mr Butlar and cousin Elizabeth sent us word we might expect them about three weeks ago, and we have been expecting them ever since, but they have not called yet, I have heard from Remsen quite frequently since I have been here and was very glad to hear that Uncle has recovered his health. How is Cousin Sarah now? is she any better than she was last winter? I should be so happy to hear she was

recovring, Tell her I have finished the border of the quilt she gave me and nearly sewed the blocks of the centre together it looks beautifuly, Frances drew cotton underneath the leaves in the vine it adds to the beauty very much, after I quilt it, which I will do as soon as we get settled and arranged here. I will send or bring it to her that she may see how pretty it looks. Where is cousin Jane all this time, that she has not written me a word does she think she has given us all the advice needful and think she will be silent not to give us time to think upon what she has said? if so tell her she is taking the wrong course, it would be better to remind us of it occasionally, to be sure that it would not be forgotten, or come herself and see that we practice all the economy she advised, we think the last would be prefrable. If she thinks so and will act accordingly we will endeavour to make her visit as agreeable as possible, which I think will not be very difficult with the pleasant home and kind friends we have and every thing pleasant connected with it, any one could hardly help being happy here, you will think I am getting to be quite enthusiastic on the subject, but if you think so call upon us and you will say then that I have every reason to be well pleased with my new relations and home and would be very ungrateful if I were not happy in the enjoyment of such blessings, friends as kind and affectionate as I could wish and health very much improved since you saw me, and Thomas health is very good at present. How are cousins Lewis and Margaritt how does M like keeping

Store I hope as well as she expected why did they not call, when they went to New York we were very much disappointed as we expected to see them when they came to Utica. Tell them I wish them to write me a long letter If they do I shall be very glad to receive it and will answer it immediately Sister Frances sends her love to you all, and accept a share of the same from your Niece and Nephew, this from your affectionate Niece Mary R. Lewis

If you will please send my trunk by the Stage - Direct to Thos D Lewis Utica to be left at their office that is Joy & Co Line and please to write and let me know when to expect it. If Cousin Lewis wishes his trunk now I will send it if he is in no hurry I will keep it untill Fathers family have moved

Lynn Sept 2nd 1865
Dear Cousin
I recieved you welcome letter last Wednesday. week, Thomas was here that day (I think) However I have had so much on my hands since, or I should have answered before I have moved again since I wrote you now I have a room all to myself, and I assure you I consider it a great luxury as well as a comfort. to have a quiet place where I can sleep or rest whenever I feel the need of it, I have been in this room three days, and can see that I gain in strength every day. There are three windows, facing the East, West, and South, so that I have a good circulation of air at any time. I think you must have had a really

hot day yesterday, it is usually so much warmer there than here, and the thermomiter Stood at 90 in the shade here yesterday afternoon, my room was quite comfortable notwithstanding, that, if I could only have had this room in the first place I should have gained so much more. I have felt all the time before as if I was losing time and gaining nothing. Just for the want of a little quietness, I had a letter from Sarah last Wednesday she says Alex continues to improve though slowly does not walk without his crutches. though he can walk a few steps without either crutch or cane, and better than all he has gained one pound. I feel now that he is really better, he has been loosing all the time before, they have a room on the first floor at Mrs Midlams, so much better than going up too flights of stairs, I can think now that we shall see him well again, and I can't tell you how much

better I feel when I think of him. Sarah says her father does not seem to get very well, for that reason they have given up their rooms at Mrs Greens, and are staying at Cassville, her brother and his wife are also out of town, she says it is very lonely with nobody to drop in often and see how they are getting along. Father and Henry are there most every day, and Tomas makes quite a long call once a week, but no lady friends excepting those who are in the house she hopes I will not conclude to stay longer than next week, I do not think I shall, But she says she is perfectly content to stay in town as long as she can see that Alex is getting better. I was very sorry to hear that you had had and was still having so much sickness in the family. How are the sick ones now? is Mary able to be about yet, How are Lewis' family? John's? and all the rest, Are Uncle & Aunt feeling pretty well? Write and let me know how you all are: all the news &c, &c With Love to all I remain your aff cousin Mary R Lewis

Write me soon as I expect to start for home next week Friday will be in Utica Saturday
upside down:

Ithaca July 29th 62 My Dear Uncle, At Mothers request (I sent you a box by the American Express) in the spring for Aunt Sarah. I would have Expressed it through to Remsen if they should have done so but the express agent here would not take pay farther than Utica, and I supposed you being so well acquainted there you should easily get it. I wrote you at the time I sent you the Box, but have never heard whether you recieved it or not.  Will you please write as Mother should like to know. She is now with us With kind love to all and hoping this

will find you all in good health I remain your affectionate neice May Rankin  P.S. I passed through Utica two weeks since, and was astonished that you were so near us as I supposed it much farther. Should be very happy to see any of you in Ithaca Remember me kindly to poor Aunt Sarah. I hope she is comfortable I should be very glad to hear how she is   M. R.

New York Mills
Aug 15th 1874

My Dear Aunt & Uncle  What must you think of my negligence. I am utterly ashamed of myself. Leaving you as I did one yer ago, and not writing one word to you since and then to write as I did that I would be to your house at tea day before yesterday and then not coming myself nor sending any word. I fully intended sending you a telegram that we could not come but it entirely left my memory. I felt so grieved when it was too late. I hope I did not put you to a great deal of trouble. My note was written in such haste, that I fear it was

know that we are in a dear loving Saviours hands and that he will keep and protect us to the end. How I should love to know you all better. What a delight it would be to Mother to see you and Uncle once more. If you ever go to visit your daughter Elizabeth you must surely visit us, and I would  dearly love to have Jenny, Anna a Cynthia visit us. How often I think of Cynthia's kindness and attention to us. She was so anxious that we should have a pleasant visit and Jenny too her being the means of our delightful visit to the fall's I wish she could know how much we enjoyed them, although we would have enjoyed them much more could she have been with us. Is it not possible for her to come and make

that we never expected her to get up again, but a kind Heavenly Father has again permitted to be able to come down stairs and mingle with us She is very feeble, and I felt that I ought not to leave her, but others decided it was best for me to come. 

   I have often thought of each one of you since I left, of all your kindness to us while there, and should have  acknoledged it long ere this, had I been in health. I have suffered for some years from "congestion of the brain" and was in a fearful state of mind from the time Aunt Betsy left us last summer until the beginning of this summer my mind became clearer How fearfully dark everything was to me None can ever know until they  are aflicted in the same way But a kind Father has lifted the cloud, and oh how joyous it is to

hardly intelligible. We no sooner than decided to come than I sat down to write you. while I was writing to you they were all the time calling to me to come down stairs and finally they came  and compelled me to close my letter without saying anything that I had intended and indeed I do not know what I did write. We intended to come to the falls that day, and could not think of being so near without  seeing you all once more, but the heat  was so intense, and as my health is very poor my son and daughter decided it would not be prudent for me to undertake so labourious a Jaunt. After leaving you last summer I came to Aunt Betsy's where we had a very pleasant visit. Aunt and Josey returned home with us. Mother was delighted to see Aunt, although dear Mother was very ill, so ill

us a visit bringing one or both her sisters with her? I have not forgotten the pleasant visit I had to Sarah's  in her own "cozy home" with her own happy Husband. Long, happy and useful may her life be, and I also remmember cousin Lewis wife's kindness and attention to us. Please all accept our kind thanks  to you for your kindness to us Give our kind love to all and accept a great deal for yourselves I have anticipated so much to spend one night with you and see you once more. I hope Uncle and yourself are in usual health and also that the rest are in good health

   Please excuse all mistakes If I could do any better I would write this over, but my poor head aches so

and I fear if I do not send this something may happen that I will not write another. When I last heard from home Mother was very well for her, I expect to start for Ithaca next tuesday. My daughter Lizzie is with me. Aunt Betsys health seems poor. Josey and her Aunt Jeny has gone west. Give my love to cousin Lewis I immagine him and Jenny in the printing room & Annie among the flowers 
I know Mother would send you a great deal of love if she knew I was writing, so I will send it for her, and now 
Good bye 
from your affectionate niece 
M. Rankin  
P.S. I should be very glad to hear from any of my cousins

Yours of July 26th came to hand few days ago for which we all are greatly indebted hoping in the future to be oftener advised of each others welfare — I mailed unclear Sts. a letter to Clark some 3 weeks ago, thinking you had not recd the one already acknowledged - .

 The latest news from Lou? was Santa Fe July 24 - 65. He had just got in from the interior of Texas with cattle for Gove of which he has - contracts. - He has done well so far. But takes great risks of Body & nerves does not mention of coming home has been gone now 4 years - His address is Caf S. L. B. Franklin Texas - Anna is still at Iowa City Reese River - striving to make something - I will forward your letter and request her to write you.  I never hear her mention of receiving any letters from you for many years. 
 Father is at Home - in good Health & strength

is passed being practable in business -
Mother continues in good health, does all the work for three of us - I am busy most of the time, hope yet to see you all ere many years pass - I have had no letter from Newhall since Nov. 1857. I wrote him six months ago wish you would make some inquiry about him in relation to myself. - I have no desire or intentions of going back to him only would like to hear from him in relation to me. I also would be pleased to have Clark write me the current times of his section & I will reply in Do. 
times in Cal. are getting to be hard for poor men - I am sick of the continued dryness - which makes the dust all most intollerable it is a terror to all House Keepers = nothing but work all the time to keep clean - otherwise the climate of Cal is delightful and nearly every person leaving it desires to return = there appears to be an indescribable fassination which allures all — I am sorry to say that I do not enjoy that happy falisity that Clark

between man & wife - whereby one party is beholden to the other for that mutual support  & friendly cordiality - so necessary for the establishment of perminant prosperity and induring advancement of moral culur? which harmonises our discordant notuses to perfect unclear more fully in living in accordance to nature besides securing the greatest hapiness & substantial comforts.
unulating to more worthy acts than pass away single like the flower of the Rocks that lifts its fair head unseen & strews its withered leavs on the blast. - I suppose Mary Ann has becom set & established in the line she is yet to persue & as for you I leave for conjecture - I am sorry that you do not enjoy good health = and only those that are afflicted can appreciate what health is (it is a poor mans fortune - a rich man's comfort) - I send my love to Aunt - hoping she will have strength to support. Her bereavement for it was but the summons of the Divine Grand Master - to call him from his work - as by his kind offices and good works while on earth

He was justly entitled to recive & have the right to benefits of Christs Kingdom which are promised to all that believ therein.
Circumstance are yet to determine wheather if Mother & Father can come and see you all = Hipe deffered maketh the heart sick & all these long years in Cal. do not find us sufficiently compensated for trials & Privations undergone & to think now of leaving would perhaps be as much of an experiment as when first coming here = I perhaps could not content myself to go back to Chicago - settle down = to Busines = although I cannot judge as I know nothing of the present times &c. Cal. offers little inducement for investment of a perminent nature in fact there is nothing outside of San Francisco in real Estate that can compare to Chicago
You will please send me your Photograph. Mail per Sts. as it is more certain of coming safe. My love to Clark & Family and all inquiring friends — 
hoping that I yet may see you all and may the Blessings of God attend all our doings together with Brotherly love & Friendship -- Truly Your Cousin
J H Roberts
213 N Street Sacramento

Dear Cousin Robert, 

  Your letter has almost intoxicated my poor brain. I am not used to such spicy compliments. Mr. Thomas said something about your cleverness, and I think I must concede you to be the cleverest flatterer I ever knew! Pray forgive me if that sounds unkind, but please remember that your words are read by eyes not clouded by that deceptive distance that "lends enchantment to the viewe," several lines lined out but fully legible: and they sound strangely to us. My sisters say they would give a good deal to see that "sweet creature" of whom you write. I am not well enough versed in love lore to tell how alarming your case is, but do not put on a very bewitching look, when you sit for the likeness for me, lest I find myself in like plight. /lined out We were much grieved to hear of Aunt Anne's death. I am sorry we had no intercourse with her by letters, while living, but we used to hear of her through others, so that she did not seem

a stranger to us. I suppose you saw father's letter to his sisters giving an account of Aunt Sarah's death. During the last few weeks of her life, she very often spoke of her sister Ann, little thinking no doubt how soon she should greet her on "Canaan's happy shore". Thus one by one they pass away and the little company above is growing larger. I love to think of that. It makes Heaven itself seem dearer. My dear cousin I hardly know what to write with reference to your own great loss. Our sympathy is freely offered.  As a family, we know something what it is to pass through deep affliction, but only Jesus can speak just the right words to soothe the the troubled soul. Go to him often with your burden, dear cousin, as I know you do, and often turn over the leaves of his Holy Word, in the full belief that you will there find words of comfort and strength. May he bless even this bitter grief, then it will be better than any unblessed joy. 
Fear bitterest tears if he smile but on them like dew in the sunshine grow diamond and gem  
We would send our tenderest love and sympathy to your dear motherless children. May the storms of Earth blow lightly on them, and early fleeing to the Saviour's arms may they be shielded from many of its temptations and sins. My brother John he's here with his three little ones who have lost a loving mother. You are right - in the hope that that sick month left us without making any ravages among us. John, Jennie and Lewis, all our printers, were sick at once, so of course the Cen for a time had to lie still Jennie and Lewis were both very low. I am of the rest of us, your "wicked little Cynthia" among the number were also sick, and all of brother Lewis family. The disease was dysentery which raged very much around

Sac City  May 1856

My Dear Brother & Sister
  I received a letter from you last week, we were very glad to here from you and family  particularly  to find that Sarah's health & strength was so well  I feel ashamed to think that we as a family has treated you so unkind as not to write to you,  I receive the Cenhadwr regular now  I have not received half what you have sent me paper torn  brief? history of our lifes in Calafornia, when My family came here we went all on the ranch, John had returned from the Nothern Mines few weeks before My Wife and Daughter came, Tom was with me since he came here, I had several Men to work for Me choping wood, which was good proffitable business then in November/52 the great fire came & burned a large amt of wood for Me in Ded the great flid? came and washed quantity of wood off in the Spring/53  pay was very high $100, pr Ton and the whole vally covered with water from hill to hill in Many places 15 or 20 Miles wide  I went to look where I could get grass to cut, I found some

Sac City = Sacramento

in four or five Miles distance from my place wild clover the best that I ever Saw, Much better? than the clover that we use to have in Wales  very heavy crops, I commence cutting on the 28th of April it was rather to early then, the following week it was very good. I made all haste I could to get to Market first: I had to carry it 4 Miles to the River and then a boat to Sac City  I had a boat that would carry 50 tons, of hay  I made preparation to have 200 tons down in very short time  I contracted to have 200 tons Baled with a patent press, of which I was to pay $6.00 pr Ton, after I had large quantity cut down, Rane came and spoiled much of it  on its way down I page torn the Boat got snaged, and had to through it all over board to save the boat and got it off & The price came down and the price of wood came down, also and I sold some that I could not get pay for I sold to brick makers, they sold the Brick to the Masons,  Masons built for Merchants and they failed to pay, consequently I could get no pay, and I was Render Most pennyless although I had some property on hand  Hay wood Horses hogs & I moved my family to the City  My business was Mostly in the City, In Jan h? 64 I left my business to my sons and went to the Mines to try my luck as I came here to Mine.  I went to Hangtown, bought a clame

in company with other two Men, for which I pad $100, It did not prove to be very proffitable one  In May took up another clame on the bank of South fork of American river, I certainly thought that I would make my pile? then  I worked there all Summer, Mooveng much dust? and try to go to the botom, I could not get down on acct of water  I had a large pump going by water night and day yet could not keep it dry all the time,  I had many applicants to purchase 1/2 of it  I did not wish to Sell, to Rase Money I Sold 1/2 of it for $400, Cash ? soon? about 2 or 3 weeks longer and had to give it up on account? - ripped paper]] naghbours next door was takeen it unclear by the pounds, he sold our clame to them for a trifle the following Summer they woorked into it from their woorks it paid rich?, I moved from there few miles of Hangtown bought Interest in a ditch there, It is supplyed from a small creek, this last winter we have had but very little rane, consequently I could get but little water and that proved a falier,  My Family lived Most of the time in the City, we have comfortable house and a lot 40 by 160 all paid for, Anna is in public school.  Tom in the employ of the Pacific express Co. he is now a Messenger on the River to & from San Franico here

John is in the wood business boating wood down to the city he can do well at that he can make this Somer $150 to 200 or more pr month, he brings down about 75 cords to a load there is great demand for wood here in Sumer to burn brick,  So the Children are all doing well,  I have made but very little for two years,  We enjoy very good health  Anna has been afflicted with the Rumatism the first year after she came here  Tom's health is much better than in Chicago, he came in July 52 and was elected torn paperlkin a County Assessor (a fast young torn they paid in County Scrip $12 pr day for 60 days.  I am in no business, have been here little over a month  I am going at something soon,  I send you with this a weekly San Francisco Bulletin  I could not get a Steamer paper in the City great demand for papers this Morning to send to the States an account of the Great ?..utement? in San Francisco.   I have some time ago send you the Pacific for three or 6 Months also the Sacramento Union, I have not learned whether you have received them or not
on left side
I shall send you a paper from here for months coming? and shall write again soon  We join in love to you and family  I remain your affectionate Brother   J. T. Roberts

Jefferson May 19th 1858 
Dear Cousin

Your letter of the 12th reached me last week. I am sorry we missed a visit from you just because Uncle Sam didn't do his duty But we shall see you in vacation and long is your vacation. Perhaps cousin Anna will come before. We should be glad to have her come and stay as long as she can To be sure we have very little society here and very little to interest a stranger but then we shall have all the more time to visit together and I will

do what I can to make it pleasant for you If you would like to have father meet you in C---- please write some time before so that we may get the letter time Enough. The Fond du Lac cars which pass here leave C----- only at 7 in the Evening and Early in the morning (before 9 I believe). The omnibus which I spoke of in a former letter has stopped. I have written to Aunt Everett and Father is going to add a line I shall mail it to day and I do hope she will come I suppose you will think this short if not sweet but I cannot write more as it is nearly time to close the mail and I have yet another letter to write So
shortness will not curtail the length of my love and so till I see you adieu Your aff cousin M A Roberts

Boonville  Nov 3d 1864

Dear Cousins
  Cousin Mary told me I had better forewarn you of my coming or I might have to foot it a mile or so in the mud - or she said I would n't find any Hacks or Omnibuses at the depot and if I'd write you when to look for me, you would probably meet me there  So I send you this to announce myself - I shall leave here Saturday on the afternoon train which they tell me starts about 2 P.M.  My best love to you all   E, Ottie Roberts
