Buffalo Aug 9 1865 
Rev Robt Everett.  
Dear Sir 

 Your very Kind letter to Mother. giving her so interesting an account of Aunt Sarah s sickness, and the sad inteligence of her death. reached her last week from Ithaca. I do not Know that you have heard of my removal to this city. I came here with my family last fall and have engaged in business here. And the summer here being very cool and favorable for mothers health she is spending it here with us, and as she is quite feeble and it is quite a task for her to write, I offered to be her Amanuensis  It gave her great comfort  to have you write her so fully about

McChains works and the weekly religious papers. She spends most of her time reading, It is a great comfort that She can spend the remnant of her days so comfortably and happily with her childrn She goes from one to the other as she pleases.  She recd a letter a few days since from her sister Elizabeth. from Chester, England. She is now Mrs Jones, formerly Mrs Pew, her sisters Jane  Elenor and Sarah are all state living. Jane & Elenor in Wrexham and Sarah at Stockport. her Husband Mr Shepard is an invalid and a great charge to her, as he has lost the use of his lower limbs, is a heavy man and hard to handle. Mother will remain with us during the summer and perhap in the fall go to New York to spend the winter with her Daughter Louisa, or in Ithaca with Mrs Rankin. Louisa & family have just been here spending 3 or 4 weeks with us. we all join in love to you and all the members of your family. Ever praying that you may be found an unbroken family in heaven yours truly in behalf of Mother Everett 

S P Sherwood

abundantly reward you and your family for it. "In as much as ye have done it unto one of the least of his little ones" pronounced on your head will be enough from the blessed master to richly reward you for your earthy toil & care. Mother has often desired to go to Remsen for the purpose of seeing you and your family and the grave of her dear husband. But time has passed, and it has not been done and now she feels that old age is upon her, and being quite weak much of the time, she hardly has the courage to go on journeys and she has to husband her strength and be very careful of herself to keep comfortable. Her hearing is somewhat impaired so that she seldom enjoys preaching, but is very fond of her bible and good books, such as Jays Morning & Evening Exercises to

Aunt Sarah, It was very kind and considerate in you. It is an unspeakable comfort and a wonderful display of Gods mercy and love that amid all her privations and sufferings she had the blessed savior to sustain her, and even to the end.  And now we may feel that she has gone where no bodily infirmity will ever again affect her or impair he mind. She is now clothed upon with the rightousness of Christ. And mortality has put on immortality. And who could wish her back to spend another life in this sinful world. It must have been a great care to you with all your other family but God has enabled you to be a father to her and given you the disposition & grace to watch over and care for her while on earth. And he will

Ithaca Sept 15th 1860

Dear Uncle & Aunt   Mother has long been wishing to write to you, but owing to her infirm state of health has not felt able, and at her earnest regret I am writing in her behalf - She wished me to say that she was very glad to hear from you once more, and that she thanks you very much, for the pictures you sent - She says that if she ever feels sufficiently strong, she will sit for hers, and will send them to you - It was a great comfort to her, that my husband and myself visited you, and that we visited my poor father's grave - She says that she has often felt as though she would like to go there herself but there were so many things connected with his memory, so exceedingly painful, that made her feel as though she

could not do it, and now for a few years, her health has been so poor, she has not felt able to undertake such a journey. She says she would like very much to see you, and thinks about you very often, but at her time of life, can hardly expect to realize her wish. She suffers very much with the disease in her stomache, and is very weak, but is not confined to her bed, for which she feels very grateful. Tell cousin Jenny that she must not forget her promise to write to me - I have not forgotten mine, but if you have received my husband's letter, you will know why I am not at home, and Gertrude's illness has prevented my writing sooner. Gertrude came here to spend her summer vacation at Mrs. Rankins, and about three weeks ago was taken very sick with inflamation of the bowells, but she is now much better

and I hope to return with her next week. She has had several attacks before, but none so severe as this one, so I was sent for and have been here nearly two weeks - I left my husband and Charlie alone, and I feel anxious to return as soon as Gertrude is able to stand the journey - We had so many thing to talk about when we were at your house, that I am afraid that I forget to say what I ought to - There were many things pleasant connected with one short visit at your house, and some painful memories were awakened, but I will not speak of them now -  My sisters and their husband's are quite well, and so are the children, with the exception of my Gertrude and Louisa Storms - who is now at Clifton Springs - Her mother is with her - She is a frail, delicate looking girl and for some months past, her

her shoulders, seemed to be growing out of shape, and they have felt considerable anxiety on her account - Dr Foster has examined her case, and says she has a curvature of the spine, but hopes, on account of her youth, that she will out grow it - She is fifteen years old.  Mr Storms is in Ithaca with the two other children - We are having uncommonly cold weather here, and it really seems as though we have already had a long Fall.  Mother sends a great deal of love to all of the children, as well  as to yourselves, and hopes to hear from you again  If cousin Elizabeth is still with you please give my love to her and her husband - I wish we could have staid to see them - but hope we may have that pleasure some other time.  I intend to write  to cousin Jenny as soon as I return home. My time is wholly occupied here - And now dear uncle and aunt, I must close with a great deal of love to yourselves, and all the cousins, not forgetting, cousin Lewis and his wife

  from your aff niece
    J.E. Sherwood

26 Delaware St  Buffalo Sept 3. 1866
Dear Uncle & family 
We arrived home safely the same day we left you. and found those of our family who were at home quite well and happy to see us again as we were to be reunited to them again  We recd a letter Saturday, saying that our absent one (Gertrude) was quite ill. You know we told Jan she was on a visit to Ithaca. My wife & Emma leave tonight to nurse her and bring her home as soon as she is well enough. Mother has been quite ill again with her usual periodical difficulty, but was recovering again, and we hope by next letter to hear that she is quite restored again. Dear old mother she cannot stand many more such turns. She will soon be through her Earthly pilgrimage, and then I believe, will enter to the rest  prepared for the people of God." She appears to be loosing her Anchorage to this world daily. and trimming her sails for the endless voyage of Eternal life. We wrote her all about our visit to you and I Know it will be a great comfort to her that we saw you, and visited the grave of her
Jane will write from Ithaca if she can spare the time

dear departed husband, I told her how nice the grounds were, and that the Stone was in good condition, and that Kind hands and thoughtful hearts had planted an Evergreen at the foot of the grave. all of which I know will be gratefully considered by her. We have thought much and talked much, about our short, but pleasant visit with you. and shall never forget it. Inclosed we send your cards of Janie Charles & Gertrude, We have none of Emma or mine. but will have soon when we shall send you one of Each. We have had a great demonstration here today. recieving our President and his more honored attendants. without the latter me thinks he would receive but little attention. He will find his popularity deminishing as he moves westward. This war has cost too much treasure & blood. to let treason go unpunished, and Loyalty unrewarded. Congress and the People, under an overruling Providence will set matters right. I go to Alden 20 miles from here tomorrow to hold our County S School convention and hope to have a good time and get a fresh baptism of the Holy Ghost to Enable us to do more for building up the Redeemers Kingdom the coming year than during the past. with united love to you all we remain your affectionately Mr. & Mrs S P. Sherwood

Ithaca Mch 21/75 

Dear Mrs. Everett   Our hearts are turned towards you in sympathy while under gods affecting hand. We have learned through Mrs Hughe's family at York Mills sending us a paper that your dear companion has departed for the heavenly home. And is now numbered with the redeemed & ransomed souls in that House not made with hands. Eternal in the Heavens. Yes dear friend there is no doubt of his having had an abundant entrance into that rest. It is hard to part with him but you may be comforted in the reflection that the separation will not be a lengthy one. God in his love and mercy has permited you to dwell together on earth longer than the

average term of earthly companionship. We can imagine your looking back on the past union as one of unusual length not only - but attended all the way. With innumerable blessings & no doubt you many exclaim with the Psalmist. "I cannot recount one of a thousand of his benefits." It is an unspeakable blessing to have had such a God loving God fearing & God serving companion as you had, and a rich legacy to his family. The consistent faithful life he has lived before his family & world is worth more than all the earthly riches.  He has not lived in vain, and the world is the better for his having lived in it. He leaves a large number of dear friends to mourn with you his loss.
on left side and across top:
I am happy to state that my health is quite restored again and I have again engaged in my former business with good prospects of success. My son Charles has a fine wife & two very nice little girls 4 & 6 years  Hoping to hear from you soon and with an united love to all your family and especially to Sarah whose precious little Effusion of poetry on our departure

But his meek & quiet influence will live many, many years to come. "Mark the perfect man, and the upright, for the end of that man is peace." Precous in the sight of the Lord are the death of his Saints. They rest from their labors & thir works do follow them.   
Dear Mother Everett, felt very sad when she heard of his death. She tells me to say to you that you have been much in her thoughts for many years, and she has often wished she could see you occasionally, and if you can ever see your way to come accompanied by any members of your family, we shall all be most happy to see you. It is to bad that we have had no corespondnce with any of your family in so long a time.
continues from top of previous page:
our departure from your house I have just been reading I hope she is very happy in her married relation Tell her I should like to know if she finds much poetry in the realities of married life  We should like another epistle from her gifted pen  Yours in love & sympathy   S P Sherwood

My wife thinks she wrote last and now - do let us hear from some of your family giving us some account of Uncles last days & departure  also concerning the other members of your family. Mr Rankin and Storms & my family are all well as usual. You probably are aware that Mrs Rankin is in very imperfect health, and has had sad turns, still  She is very much better than she has been. Our oldest daughter Gertrude who was married last fall & went to Brooklyn to live, has been sick much of the time. She had Dyptherea early in the fall & has not entirely recovered from it yet. My wife has been with her about 4 weeks this Winter. The weather has been severely cold since 1st Jany and may have been call from earth in our vicinity especially among the aged. We are daily admonished to be also ready.  Dear Mother is now in her 85th year and although she suffers a great deal from her stomach yet she is up and around her room nearly every day
on left side:
and her mind is clear as ever & she reads a great deal  She has every comfort she needs and is looking for the time of her departure as near at hand. She joins with us in much love & sympathy to you all

Rosa  August 2nd 1827

 My dear Brother   I have sat some time hesitating to whom I should address my letter, but finding a letter written by you and my sister to be the last received, and as you have there favored me with a part I thought it would be an acknowledgement and would avail myself of the pleasure - It was written in Ortes? and received in May (and I had the week previous to its reception written a letter to my Sister which I hope she received) and along with it a letter to Mr Lloyd Kilford and a Parcel of newspapers which were very acceptable   My Father and Mother took a ride last week in a Car to Bangor and left my brother Thomas very poorly having caught cold the day after they arrived, and my Mother has since his return been particularly uneasy and anxious that I should write and request of you not to stay in America to lose your health in a similar way, after being informed of your having an attack of the same fever two succeeding Summers it has created in her a fear (indeed I may add in us all)  that your health will be so much impaired if you stay much longer that you will not be able to reverse it, for we greatly fear it is so with poor Thomas  as the least wetting or damping his feet will immediately occasion him to be so asthmatic and not be able to be in bed at night which was the case when my father and mother were there for he was up most part of the night his prospects for a living are very promesing there if he had his health established;  little Thomas is with us and has been for some months they expect an increase in the family soon

Bangor, Wales

We have been repeatedly told that the Church of Carnarvon have sent an invitation to you after there Assembly which was the beginning of last month, to come over, but whether or not you need not for a moment fear but that there will be a Church ready to receive you whenever you come  it is still at times reported that you are on the way coming  We had a Union Meeting last Friday at the Green the opening of the small Chapel or as it is called (Ysgoldy) and there were present several good preachers viz Mr Williams Wern. Mr Jones Mr page torn  Mr Owens Rhescal-Narius? Mold - Ridge, Bala - Davis Llanfair  Ishmael Jones and several others who preached excellent sermons and it was quite a delightful meeting  John's house at Meusydd Brwyn was open for their accomodation almost all the Preachers dined there and many other it is about a quarter of a mile from there house - There were meetings held at Waen - and Moelfre preceding it - this week there is an Assembly in Anglesea - Nathaniel and I have been about three weeks ago in Merionethshire at a Missionary Meeting at Bala and an Assembly at Llanuwchllyn both which meetings appeared to be crowned with the presence of the Lord in a great measure there were upwards of sixty preachers at LLaunwchllyn.  Mr Pierce of Wrexham and Mr Jenkins of Oswestry were the only two that addressed us in English at Bala - next month there will be a meeting at Llanbrynmair when Mr Samuel Roberts is to be ordained as copastor with his Father - and on the 21st of Sept will be our Assembly at Denbigh the opening of Ruthin Chapel will be the same week and other meetings in Flintshire - there is a young man at Ruthin of the name of Price whom they at present intend having as there Minister   I wish we might cherish the hope of seeing you at some of these meetings but we shall I assure you, of seeing you in future meetings.  In reference to Elizabeth's health also my Mother thinks it is very unwise of you staying there - We hope Henry and David enjoy good health as we have not been informed to the contrary but as for my Sister I find she is not

so strong as when here we should be glad to know whether David remains in the same place. I mean my next letter to be to one of my brothers  to see if there is not a possibility of having a letter from them again should be glad if brother Henry and Sister would muster a letter between them but fear my requests are vain - I am without Davids address so cannot write to him, without hearing further.  Mrs Williams  Pwllheli brother John Mother in law was buried about five weeks ago - John has been very comfortably married - he is at present much engaged with the tythe as our Corn harvest is just commencing the crops in this neighborhood are but small much less than in any part of Wales or I might say in the Kingdom for the papers give a very promising account elsewhere  it is only a part of Denbigshire that has been so dry; but we need make no complaints as we have not been pinched with any thing either last year or this had plants of straw and hay which was very scarce in some places; I shall leave it to John to state particulars of this kind when he writes. The circumstances of the Church at Denbigh continues much the same as wh paper tornte last there was one received last communion  the Sabbath torn not very flourishing We here know but little I fetorn of the convetorneak of as being so evident in America  the congregation tornp pretty well, we have had Mr Dean with us six weeks preaching in our Chapel every Sunday evening after the Welsh sermon which was over at seven the Chapel was was then quite full and respectably attended  he was lately married to a lady of ten thousand pounds fortune and has brought his wife to Tros y Park to spend there honeymoon - We all as a family enjoy good health my Mother as well as I can ever recollect her, Nathaniel is grown quite a man, our family is small, you may suppose in comparison to what it used to be so that there is torn of unclear & seen you when you come, I intended writing a part of this to my Sister but find myself coming to near a close - my Aunt Liverpool enjoys her health but very indifferent - I was told last week that all your relations were well at New Market  I have not seen any of them this long while but was told that they write to you frequently -

Ishmael Jones desired me to present his best respects to you and many more do which I find too tedious to name he has lately returned from Hackney Accademy, but is still a Welsh man.  Miss Betsey Williams Ruthin is married to a Mr Morris an Artelier Attorney at Ruthin  We have lately established a Club for the relief of the poor members belonging to our Chapel which which is likely to be the means of much good  it is my turn to be one of the vesttors this evening which makes me turn
continues on bottom:
over my letter quickly - please to present my Father Mother Nathaniel and may our kind love to Henry and wife  David and Sister and also to Elizabeth, John Roberts  Lewis, and Mary  and accept the same from us all to yourself   With believing me to be your   Affectionate Sister   Jane Roberts

Denbigh 12th March 1853

My dear Brother & Sister

 I was much delighted in receiving a letter from you last week although short it was acceptable after so long a Silence, the day I received it I was going round the Town with Mrs. Price to collect to the Lillip" Society and I got Tig? Gwyth Robert forthwith and forwarded it to you as instructed, two numbers were only printed; the London Edition of Uncle Tom in Welsh I proved last Wednesday and posted it the same day, and I am hastening to write a few lines to beg you to let me know whether you have received them or not; The others I shall continue to send as they are printed but I am inclined before I proceed to quarrel with you for not allowing me the opportunity of making you the small return, for the obligation I am under to you for the Cenhadwr for so many years

I beg to say that if there is any thing I can send to you at any time I shall be most happy to do so and you might thus secure my correspondence occasionally. I sometimes profess to be able to write on business tolerably put all other letter writing at present seems out of my forte Let your next commission come without any of your pretty Dollars, we are not quite wanting in gold coins this side of the Atlantic We were glad to hear so much about Brother John and his family may I beg of you when you receive a letter from him to let us know more and also his address, I was sorry to find that your daughter Sarah is still an invalid, Mrs. Smart the Rector of Henllan's wife has been confined to bed for many years with an affliction of the spine, and she is now almost well under the treatment of some person in England who has cured many quite hopeless cases.

 My dear Sister you quite owe a visit to your native land, if your daughter can bear it bring her over this

summer, I need not tell you that it would afford us very great pleasure to see you, and if she found a cure you would not regret your trip

 Our families here are well Thomas and his family have removed to Rhyll since last May they are doing well in keeping a Milliners Shop the daughters go to London 2 or 3 times a year to get the fashions, Rhyll you would not know it full of Villas Terraces and promenades &c &c. The Chester & Holyhead Railway going through gives it unclear  My brother Nathaniel's eldest daughter Ann? just left school, a fine girl almost full grown at 14, and as like you I may say, as any of your own children, they are all receiving good education
 My two little ones are at the same school the eldest is boarding there since last midsumer, she attends our Chapel on Sunday page torn was admitted to the Lords table the last Sabbath for her first time, she was anxious for years to do so, she was under religious impressions from her infancy, I must draw to a close and keep a

I thought it best to send by Evgth Farm in the form I got it, as it made a trifling difference in the postage I would see by the postage advertizement in the Cenhadwr - I am glad to find that you are going to have Railway through Remsen by when I come to see you with my sincere thanks for the Cenhadwr which is the only periodical I now recieve and with kind love to all your family and brother Henry's, I remain your affectionate Sister Jane Williams

Mr John Davis Llasedaper? they were burying lately, his wife has been dead some time old June Palmer also is gone  You do not tell us anything about brother Henry and his family I hope they are all well, I am afraid of prmising to write to him for fear of a failure

Denbigh Bulith School
 4th September 1853

Dear Brother & Sister

 I have long wished to write to you in answer to your request to know about the treatment Mrs. Smart underwent for the cure of her spine the reason I did not write earlier on the subject was expecting her return home. She has not yet returned but intends doing so at the end of this month I went to Henllan this week to gain all I could from Mr. Smart respecting her treatment he often visits her and had returned from her last week she rode with him in a gig for two hours and walked some distance in his arm, her case you will understand had been of twelve years standing and she was for most of the years not able to bear the least elevation of her head, not able to set up at all Mrs Jones the person who undertakes her care has not the least doubt that under God's blessing she will be entirely cured, if she remained a little longer under the treatment. She will accompany her home and remain with her a fortnight, and Mr. Smart says that if she is not well in the spring he will take her back under the treatment

for a final cure, now as respects the treatment I cannot say much this Mrs. Jones has an ointment with which she rubs the body all over for two hours, twice a day, her mode of rubbing is like the Champooing in India not unpleasant nor painful, It was a gentleman having returned from the East Indies that practised this treatment with great success and his patients became so numerous that he was obliged to teach this person to assist him and she has had the satisfaction not to have sent any away without receiving great benefit in most cases quite cured, some like Mrs. Smart anxious to return to their families before a complete cure is effected her terms are ten pounds a month and one pound for the oil or ointment which makes S? £11 a month the oil she will not sell to any one nor tell what it is, she first took what she called perspiring oil and rubbed Mrs. Smart well with that and wrapped her well up and she was soon in a profuse persipiration after that she took the other oil for four hours daily and made her drink about a pint of porter daily hot, she did not allow her to take any thing cold she chiefly lived upon beef and puddings but no tarts or pies I believe I have said about all I have learnt from

Mr Smart if there be any more questions you will like me to ask I shall be most happy to do so, he is quite in esctasy witht he present state of his wife's cure, and says he is determined upon publishing or advertizing Mrs Jones, so as to make her better known, he says she has cured some from all part of the kingdom but he did not know whether she had any fr America

 I hope you receive Ty Ewyth Rhoberts, they are sent as soon as they are out of press, the whole of Kruikshanks has been long sent I feel greatly indebted to you for the Cenhadwr that you kindly send me which keeps up a little monthly communication with you or between us I should say indeed it is my chief source of information respecting my son? as well as America I have but little time now for reading my school is the little world in which I move and to which all my attention is given we have now a little respite  a few weeks holydays, we had lately a government examination and after that a public examination, and both schools had an additional pupil teacher address to it I am thankful to say we are all as a family this side the ocean well, excepting brother Thomas, he is at times very poorly, has had great swelling in his limbs

Smarts's please to give my kind love to brother Henry and family and say we should be glad to hear from him with love to yourselves and family

 Believe me to remain
 My dear brother & sister
 Yours affectionately
 Jane Williams

You must escuse this hurried letter I hasten to write with a bad pen after ten at night as I now go a little from home and I thought you might write if you wished me to make any further enquiries with this Mrs Jones before she leaves the

Rhydyfen 8 August 1859

My dear Brother & Sister,

  Many thanks to you both for your kind & sympathizing letter which I intended to have acknowledged long ere this. But as I felt rather unnerved with attending to lingering illness and afterwards the deathbed of my dear child I have been moving about, for a little longer. I am now staying at my Nephew's house near Corwen Rob Piersen Roberts he & his mother have removed from Ganllwd to this place. They live in a very pretty house on a small farm his attention is mostly given to a Saw & turning Mill, that he has close by here. My Cousin Mary from Highgate is staying here, with me/ Aunt Highgate as we say

Dear Brother & Sister, both you and myself have had to drink of the bitter cup in our times; but there is much that is sweet & soothing mixed with it. When we reflect on the present enjoyment of our dear children for ever freed from all sin and the sorrows that accompany it. Dear Ann Mary had never been strong in health. She had the Bronchitis for several years, always a cough, very troublesome in winter but she was cheerful and in good spirits always, enjoying herself she walked to the top of Paster Idins? last summer with ease. But with the cold weather the cough came more severe than usual and she left school the end of Oct, she called in the spring and the Docter thought that a passage to America might quite restore here but our Allwise God saw otherwise Her lungs became ulcerated in the end of April and she then rapidly sunk. When I asked her if she did not think she was going to leave us

she said "the Lord has not shewn me that I am going to die now, but indeed perhaps I am  I am very weak Oh it would be delightful if I should go to Heaven now.  after this she daily evinced great anxiety to go soon, one day she said I am very thin, but God has raised many from the border of the grave, and if I am raised I am quite safe I am on the Rock but if I die Oh I shall be happy to go to Jesus now at the same time she often said that she wished God to do his own will with her. she often sympathized with me and said she knew I would feel her loss much; as we had always been together and indeed I do, the blank cannot easily be filled up I had given up my school at Christmas. I sometimes think of taking Lizzy home and begin a private school either in Denbigh or elsewhere We trust "our steps shall be ordered by the Lord"

I have a young man from the Bank boarding with me. I begged of him to call one day, he went to Liverpool at the unclear office. They told him they had received the sovereigns from Wm Jones, and that you were not in their debt at present. As for the Banner you must allow Brother Nathaniel and myself to settle that little difference yearly?, in part compensation for the Cenhadwr which you so kindly continue to us; were it not for that all our intercourse would have long been at an end to all appearance we are all much interested in what family news you send us now and then in your letters too. Could you not give us brother John's address he is entirely estranged from us as I am now from home and my sons taken up with going about you must excuse this short note I hope to hear from you again very soon when I shall try to write fuller and also to my niece Cynthia my Cousin nephew & Mrs Roberts with me to give you them but love accept also that of your affectionate Sister J Williams

Denbigh 27th Oct 1860

My dear Brother & Sister   When I received your letter page torn 4th August I did not intend leaving page torn a time elapse without adknowledge torn it  The Cenhadwr for this month again torn unded? me I wish we could manage to keep up a more regular correspondence  - it would bring us into a closer contact with each other, and also keep our young generation from being entirely estranged  Will you offer my congratulations to your Son Lewis and his wife on the birth of their daughter  I hope she may be spared to be a great comfort to them. I was sorry to find in the Cenhadwr that they are suffering so much at Kansas from the effect of drought, that and the unsettled state of the country must make you very

anxious especially your Son Johns family  But it is a comfort that there is an Almighty Power that governs all, on whom you may "cast all your cares". I hope & trust they may be spared to see and enjoy better times in the land of their adoption  The coming Election for President will no doubt be a very exciting time with you, as well as very important. The time must soon come that Freedom will prevail over Oppression, although it may appear rather dark at times now.  I forwarded the letter to Machynlleth at once when I received it - We are much obliged to you for the little family news you sent in your last letter, such is always very acceptable  We as a family are through many enjoying health and many comforts

My Cousin Highgate begs to be very kindly remembered to you both and family. We often come across you all in our conversations  Tell your young folks that we shall try to send them our Portraits in the Spring, if we are spared so long  I spent a few very pleasant days at Llandudno this Summer at the house of Mrs Jones, Mr Jones New Market's daughter, they have 6 grown up children and are living very comfortable at beautiful english Chapel  were? built there within 3 years past and is now too small altho they said about eight hundred were present the Sunday I was there  They are going to enlarge it next Spring  They have collected about £500 towards  doing so. Some Towns on our Coast grow as fast as your American towns  Mr Parry (Gwalehmai) is Minister there married to one of the daughters of Afongoela?  The families there wished to be Kindly remembered to you both.  With kind love to yourself and all your family and Brother Henry and his family  From your affectionate Sister  Jane Williams   Do let us hear from you again soon

and some other places with such agency  It is by employing woman to carry the Bibles about Town and going into the houses to read and pray together that well become them and selling the Bibles by small installments  We know as yet but two Bible woman, one for Henllan Street and one for the Paslle, Their duty lies among the very lowest of the inhabitants  In connecion with it we sell clothing by small instalments and meet the woman once a week in the Free Reading Room to help them to make their clothes and read and give little advice during sewing time. I hope it may prove a blessing to many  We are still without a Minister here and to all appearances are likely to be so for sometime yet  The congregation continues very fair but we seldom know any additions to our members  Mr Rees of Liverpool was here for a short time last night  My Brother and he were talking over their intended visit to America in the Spring  I am obliged to you for your invitation but have at present no prospect of coming. My brother will very likely go, if nothing prevent the two Reest? from going

They are getting their harvest all in at Rosa this week, The very wet Summer we have had has thrown it back so late  My brother has been thinking of writing to some of you and will I expect soon  So, I need say no more about them  My Cousin Margt has just come to Highgate having been for some months at her nephew at Corwen (Cousin Roberts Son)  Cousin John has sent his daughter to London to School he still lives by Dolgelle (alone) Mrs? Ellis brother Thomas's daughter has one child 7 months old, her Sister & Mother are well at Rhyl all are doing very comfortable  Mrs Ann Hughes from Gronant (your Sister) was here lately, She is still strong & hale  She was quite delighted to hear some of your letters, and of your daughters read to her  She begged to be kindly remembered to you when I wrote

My own daughter is now head teacher at the school where she was educated at Denbigh. Will you tell her cousin Cynthia that she intends writing to her very soon, her time has been much occupied while at Pare's and since she has been at Miss Stenhoors or she would have written. My family just now consists of myself, a young man boarding with me & a little servant girl. I have still very frequent longings for my dear departed child, having always had her at home with me, and being of a most affectionate nature makes me long the more. May it but had me to think more of that world of eternal joy that I turst she is now enjoying. I have been dusily engaged this last few weeks, with a Bible or Female Mision that we are trying to establish at Denbgh. They have done much good in London

Mrs Parry your Cousin. (formerly from Holliwell) desires to be very affectionately remembered to you Mrs Evans Grocer's? death I suppose you have seen in the papers, indeed I think you see all the news amongst us. of such kind through newspapers

 31st Dec^er I did not finish my letter last Thursday expecting to see brother M In the mean time I had the pleasure to receive your letter to him & myself I sent it to Rosa the same day, he has written or is going to write to you unclear I have sent the letters enclosed to their respective places

they are my opposite neighbors living in the school house wh makes it very pleasant to us - the rest of the family keep a Milliners Shop in Rhys and are doing well. My Brother N, and family are tolerably well, but you will hear from him soon I dare say, he is gone to the Christmas meeting to Ruthin today — Wm Piece our Minister is going to Utica I believe in April next. he is at least leaving us at that time and says he is going to America. We have no very pleasant news to communicate to you as to the State of religion in this part

It was quite a treat for us to receive so much family news fr you
 Is there no hopes of any of you coming to the old country to see us, I wish I had some enticements to lay before you, as I see no hopes of coming to see you — We are going to commence a Railway from Rhyl, to Denbigh this spring so that travelling is very expeditious from there here, on the water and both sides of it. They are going to start a Paper in Denbigh shortly. I believe Mr. Wm. Rees is coming here to reside and take part in the Editorship of it with Mr. Gee and others

I will see that you will get it when it first comes out
Accept my sincere thanks for the Cenhadwr Mr Ridge Bala formerly has begged the loan of the last fr me he desired me to say that Baclyn y Bala was sending many Cofion to you hoping to hear from you again as a family very soon I am

 Your Sympathizin? Sister
   Williams

My dear Uncle and Aunt

  Allow me to address a few lines to you expressive of my deep sympathy with you in the loss you have lately sustained by the death of my cousing although there is no cause of regret as there is sufficient evidence that he was an humble follower of his Blessed Lord. I should have the greatest pleasure in receiving a note from any of my cousins should they feel disposed to write. I am 

My dear Uncle and Aunt
ever your affectionate niece
Lizzie Williams

Fairholme, Denbigh.
21 Febry 1877

My dear Sister   I was very pleased to receive your last letter. It must have passed mine to you on the sea as I received it soon after writing mine to you. I have seen in the Cenhadwr only by very lately that there was a Memorial to be set up for your dear departed Husband  I was extremely glad to see it and thought I should much like to add my mite towards it  I enclose a draught for £5 you can probably get something more for it being english money: Mr Michael Jones of Bala told me that he

would subscribe to it, too he asked me what they intended to expend upon it. We are all tolerably well here. I see my brother every week  his daughters families are fairly well  The Rhyl Cousins, we see pretty often  Lizzie is gone there today  I had a severe attack of Inflimation of the Lungs. and was in bed all January and do not go but little out of my room yet.  The fever was very high and I was delirious for some days & the Dr did not think I would get through. But my Heavenly Father thought best to give me a little longer pilgrimage here I hope He will enable me to spend the time left me now to his glory than the past.   The Rosa family

have had, many, of them, much more time, than that allotted to man. in this life, but our race now will be soon run, and our Heavenly Home reached in safety I trust. Where we have all a hope to meet again. The Ocean separates us here, and age and other things that gives us no hope of meeting in this world, but there these things will be removed. You have had to go through  great & sore trobles, but the Lord has promised "to quiken and raise again from the bottom of the earth, and enlarge our greatness and and comfort us on every side"  Let us trust more to his precious promises. I hope you will now spend your evening of life in tranquility. I was glad to find that you had given up

to your Son your commpios? with the Cenhadwr; you are better without any anxiety. I am obliged to take it quietly myself - not Lizzie is not very strong. If she had the time and means to go to America she thinks, it would be the making of her. It is not for want of inclination she has not been to see you ere this  She has a very good school, two dozen Boarders, and a good number of day Scholars. Your Uncle & Eliz"ths daughter were here to tea; And we have had so many calls that my letter is very imperfect, both my brothers daughter desired this Kind love to you all  Please to give my Kind love to brother Henry & family when you see them  Lizzie join me in Kindest love to yourself and family  Your affectionate Sister  Jane Williams

Brooklyn
 Oct 27/59

Dear Uncle & Aunt

 Oh how glad we are that you went the vrey evening you did from N.Y. and not stay until Wednsday evening   We feel very thankfull to our heavenly Father that it so happened
 The New World after leaving N.Y. only an hour and a half brok her shaft which went throug and so of course made room for the watter which powered in and soon she was gone there were about 300 on board and it is stated that som have drowened.
 What makes me feel so glad

is his. I thought very much of praying on you to day one day longer. If I had pressed you so that you had stayed I could never forgive myself. God in his providence put in you the determination to go that very night, and with all my soul I say To his hame be the praise

 We were glad to have the letter with the few lines outside informing of you safe arival home
  Last night I had the pleasur to listen to Senator Wilson and M Greely speak on republicanism I wish you had been with n you would be delited
 Your ditifull Nephew
Thomas

Brooklyn May 10th /61
Dear Uncle

   This noon I receive a note from Rev. Mr. Buttler, a request &c & to go and by some paper for Cenhadur cover. I immeadiately went over to New York and got it at Champbell Hall &so it is the sise and verry near the colour I bought two reams and sent it with the express I hope it will come safe and in time, the price as you see as unclear ws $7 a ream, th check was 1575/oo so I have in hand of that 1.75 also I have a dollar Jennie sent to pay for daily Tribune also a balance afore of /35 so I have in hand three dollars an ten cents I asked them at the Tribune office to send you the paper for two months or the worth of one dollar. They said that the did not send it for less than four months so I did not take it what shall I do with I pay for the four months &c
  We were very sorry in not being able to receiv Cousins to stop with us while in the City, we had made preparations to receive them as well as Uncle & Aunt who we did expect — the reason was for three or four weeks Elizth felt quite sick, but we did not think that it was only a cold

but on Friday a rash brok out all over her body we were verry much frightened, the Dr. he did not know what it was, but though it was the veriloid or small pox, by this I tell you I felt bad did not know what in the wide world to do, on Saturday morning I went to the boat and found cousins but could not think of takking them home, I wanted to take them to an Hotel neear us in Brooklyn untill the Dr could deside but Mr. B had some friend we took & cariage & went there, wif & I feel very bad. I am glad to inform you it was not wat Dr. though it was but some kind of feave she is getting along well

 Your ditifull nephew
   Thomas

Brooklyn
 July 18/61

Dear Uncle

  Your letter containing $13 came safe to hand to day I forthwith got them changed the broker took the three dollar bill, but I thought myself it was bd? the first impression on the first look was desydedy unfavourable, but the broker knew better and pronounsed it good by exchange it for City Brooklyn bill
  Am glad you got the paper and the money safe. You did not owe me any balance on the other account I made a small memorandum then of the balance but it was in your favour I put it somewhere or lost it, I believe it was about a dollar, anyhow if you call it square now all right, and next time I will be more particular &c
  Thomas & myself are in good health, business in N.Y. & Brooklyn is very dull nearly at a stand
 Your Nephew
   Tom

Whitestown Sem Ca? 25  

My dear Cousin

 Long has it been since I recieved your kind letter I have neglected it so long that I am ashamed to write. I shall try to do beater hereafter. please forgive me will you. I was very glad to received your letter. It nearly did my heart good to hear from you. I enjoy myself very I like it much beater then I was afraid I should. We have exelente preye meetings three times a week There are many choosing that good part wich Mary chose. O have hapy it seems to see so many inquiring the way of salvation.

We have had quite a snow sorm today the ground was nearly covered but is disappearing fast.   I have just lade my books aside to pen a few lines to you  it is a late hour but better late than ever  would we not enjoy ourselves very much if we were together. I have been thinking about you for a day or tow;  have you writen to Cousin Ottia yet. I wrote to her about tow weeks ago.  How is Sarah geting along  tell hear that I want a peace of punken pie that she made, if she cant send it in a letter tell her that I will come after it. I think that will be werth while dont you.   I wanted to come up the meeting very much but I would have to loose a considerable if I went so I thing that I had better not.  You sed that Sarah had been sick.  has she had any more such spelss.

you asked in your last letter why I did not write  I have been very busy I have some sewing that I wanted to do do so as to be ready for cold weather. I think that I shall write cirtainly as much as once.  ask Sarah and Ann not to troubled you any more when you are writing to me if you pleas.  How are Aunt Uncle and all of Cousins give my love to all except these few lines from your aff Cousin Lettia

New York State Lunatic Asylum
July 20th 1853
Dear Uncle
I am happy to inform you that I and my wife enjoy good health we hope that you all as famaly in Steuben do enjoy the same blessing I would be verry glad to see you all. I and my wife was down in Utica last Sunday attending the welsh meeting cousins R and I invited us to dinner we had some grean? bread crackers cakes and water we made quite a dinner they were both well and doing well. H.W. Perry gave me half a dollar to pay for the Cenhadwr that you send to his Step Father in South Richland I will be going to Utica next week I shall give it to cousin Robert and he can send it by some one to you. I wrote a letter to Mother last week. I understand by the last letter that I received from the old country that Mother has given up the business entiarly and that she had but two cows to depend on for there living - - this from your Nephew Mr Jones  our verry best respects to you all -

 State asylum 
 Utica

From Frank R. Everett

Dear Uncle & Aunt

 Yours came to hand I was very glad to received it. Thanking you very much for your wishes for our dear Mary Elizabeth. My wife & Thomas say that she "taked after" you. Am happy to state that she ?nces? stay well. My Wife & Daughter thought to come up this summer but I think she will not come again, the Lady that was to accompany her has decided not to go. I should have been glad had it been so, for Uncle Robert and no one else is to babtize her - you babtized me - you married me - and y shall do the same with Mary Elizabeth. Am very sorry that I did not commence sooner to write as I can to "Cendadwr"  Instead of bothering with these papers page torn..what I will as I can stall? her? ? "Cenadwr"

I have a book called The History of the Protestant Church in Hungary. It was originally written in some of the languages of the Continent of Europe. It is very interesting &c. Containing about 50 Chapters som short and som long but not too long for a Chapter to be in a monthly. I have ten Chapters prepared for publication. I will send you the first Chapter next week for you to look over and if you think it would be good for Cenadwr, good; If not, not.  I intend to write it all in Welch not exactly a translation as there are some things in the history that would only waste place to put In. - The first chapter you may expect next week and one for each week untill the fifth or six, and then you may judge -  When I send my thing to the Editor I do not expect him to publish all; no, and also it will not make me feel hard for the same being neglected.

Lyonsdale  Jan 30 1867

 Mr Everett   

Dear Sir  Yours of 28th is recd together with drafts to the amount of 65.25 which we have put to your credit  We ordered the same kind of Paper from N.Y. that they sent so before they wrote us there was none of the same in market therfore sent you the nearest they coud get to the kind   We will get you up the thin paper and send you some of the Sat next week your further orders will have our best attention   Yours Truly  G W Ayer & Co

Mon. P.M.
Aug. 4, 1862
New Haven Addison Co. Vermont,
Beloved Brother and Sister in Christ
More than 20 long years have rolled away since I heard from you until last week. I received a letter from Mrs. L. stating that she providentially saw you in the stage, and she kindly send me your last office address. I kissed the line written by your own dear hand and remember with great respect the sweet its received from you in my sick room, and the preached word there. Oh how delightful the memory of such loved ones. How refreshing to hear from them. I have often though of you, and wondered whether you were on earth, or in heaven. It seems that you are spared for the sole purpose of bringing more souls to Christ, through the preached word. I would love a brief history
along side of letter I send you a flower from my door yard

enjoy it much. More than 20 of very dear scholars have been hopefully connected since I came here, and some we trust are now in heaven with Jesus Christ their blessed teacher. I often lay them all, (that is all that are living) on the alter of prayer before God, and leave them there, I still read my bible in course as I use to do. Finished reading through last Sat. The 70ieth time aside from reading it through about 10 times in course in the family. We finish next week the 10th time. How merciful God has been in giving me the blessed privilege of reading his blessed word so much But Oh I am a poor sinner and have not improved it as I ought, I have struggled hard to do my duty but come far short of that pure devotion which a heaven born soul should ever feel. But glory to God for dying love, and redeeming grace.

Potsdam N.Y. since last Feb. We expect him home on a visit this week, as he wishes to attend commencement at Middlebury next week. Our youngest son, is not converted. We long to see him as devoted as his beloved brother. I have had no children But have tried to do my every duty to those committed to my charge to train up for eternity, though their step mother gave them the first training. The youngest was 10 years old when I came here, 17 years next Nov. He have been to Winfield once in 2 years except once detained by severe sickness. I was sick nearly four years then carried to a water cure at Northhampton Mass. one year ago last May, and staid until the 15th of Aug. when I left in very comfortable health, and have continued so most of the time. Have a pleasant class in the sabbath school, and

of what has transpired in your church and family since our last meeting, I well remember the three oldest children. Elizabeth, Robert and Lewis. How many of your dear ones have become christians? I am sure such training as they had can not be lost, Oh how I would love to step in and enjoy a long interview with you. I wish you would come and see us. It would take but one day from Utica, and you would arrive here at 5 P.M. are not quite a mile from the Depot. (South) Come and see my pleasant house, and form acquaintance with my kind husband. We walk heart and hand together in the christian course, and have great enjoyment around the family altar, H. Barton has two sons the eldest was dedicated to God and the ministry at his birth. He graduated at Andover a year ago, and has preached at North

Thurs. eve,
My truest is all in the God of my salvation, and I feel strong in the Lord, and in the power of his might, for more than 20 years I have felt my anchor hope sure. Not one distressing doubt has arisen to disturb the peace of my soul. I have been brought nigh unto death to human appearance many times, but felt through Christ that all was well. Blessed be God for all these mercies. My aged mother was living not long since, she had been very sick, but was better the last we heard. We visited her last Fall in Home york state. She lives with my youngest brother Levi She was then very smart judgement good, faculties very bright walked about, and did a great deal of light work. She stated that she had read the bible through every year for 27 years, the old testament once and the New twice beside the general
along the side I ought to have finished my letter sooner, but have had company.

news of the day. She is able to ride out considerable, Came and spent 8 months with me when she was 87 years old. She was 93 last Dec. 19th Has lived to see the fith generation, All her children are professors of religion and nearly all of her grandchildren My twin brother, his wife and nine children are members of one Church. I sat at the table with my eldest brother 12 in a family, and all members of one church. My precious mother indulged a hope at the age of seven, and I think the number are few that have lived nearer the Saviour than she has done. Thanks be to God for christian training. My father indulged a hope at the age of 17, and has long since been in glory, and my step father too Capt Nathan Brown. I think you will remember him. Sister Hackley has been quite sick but is better. You officiated at her wedding. Pardon me dear friends for writing so much. I have opened my heart freely to you, because I love you. May the best of heaven's blessings rest upon you for ever more
yours affectionately
Parthena R. Barton
Accept our kind regards and write soon if you please.
Along the side Direct to New Haven Addison Co. Vermont

English Walls, Oswestry,
January 3th 1856,
Dear Sir
I have felt grived many times that I had so long delayed in writing to you (I often think of your great kindness towards us as a family while in America and for which I shall always cherish thoughts of you as a family) Mother and myself speaks often how desirious my dear father was a few days before he departed this life that I should write to you and enclose a small acknowledgement for your great kindness in sending the Cenhadwr   but the weeks and months have passed by my time being so occupied with one thing and another and not in a very good state of health for several months after my dear Father's death yet I had great reason to be thankful to my Heavenly Father that I was enabled to attend

to my work and the blessings of heaven seems to accompany my feeble efforts in this way I have to bless God for sparing me so good a father so long, although contrary to human nature and much more so to natural affection yet it is the Lord let him do what seemeth good, and my earnest prayer is that my Heavenly Father may abundantly recompence this loss by a greater measure of his grace to carry me through trials and temptations to which I am daily exposed to and be the means of making the feel stronger in Christ Jesus and sanctified in all my grace's The promises of the Bible are very precious to my Soul for the supported and sustained me when all seemed dark and gloomy and how comforting are those words "Our light afflictions which is but for a moment shall work out for us a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory.

I was seeing something applicable in those words in Jeremiah 9,, 21.. to you as a family as well as to ourselves since we have seen each other face to face but if we are separated from each other in this world may that gracious God continue to support us under every trial till we arrive as whole families at the Last in the Kingdom where the wicked cease from troubling and where the weary are at rest
I have no doubt but you recollect sending the following numbers of the Cenhadwr for 1844, viz January February March April, I shall feel very much oblige if it were possible for you to send one the remaining numbers for that year. It is a difficult case for me to be weaned from the Cenhadwr
Mr Joseph Evans, lent me the

December No. which he received from you and I noticed in the contents for 1855 memoir of my late dear father I shall feel exceedingly oblige if you please to favor me with that No. also. It was painful to my mind to read in that Cenhadwr of the dreadful Railway Accident by which Dr. Bullard, St. Louis met with his Death when we as a family were returning to our native country the above gentleman was going to attend the Peace Convention in Germany and was one of the first class passengers of the same vessel and I have heard him with the other Ministers deliver lectures in the first cabin several times
Mother writes with myself in kindest regards to you and Mrs Everett, &c. hoping you are enjoying your usual health as I am myself but my dear mother's health is but very indifferent 
I remain  Sir
yours ola?
Margaret Edwards.  Milliner, &c.
